Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 20 hours
5-10 depending on assignment deadlines
5 for the weekly assignments, more for the cumulative Systematic Review, but it was nicely spread out over the semester
3-7 hours
I spent approximately 5 hours a week outside of the classroom doing the assigned readings, constructing the summaries, and working on our systematic review.

Not a very engaging or effective course. The topic has the potential to be fascinating, but it is taught in such a way that students don't learn much and they are not inspired to be more interested here. The majority of the class is focused on writing a systematic review, so if you are not deeply interested in a research career, this class does not feel very relevant.
The course is outdated. The materials are from 10 years ago. Moreover, it talks little about medical related topics. A lot of homework but not useful.
This course was excellent, and I really enjoyed all of the readings and discussions we had over the semester.

This was an excellent course. It was well organized, and expectations were clearly communicated. It was great to have the experience of writing a systematic review. I feel like I gained a good understanding of the topic.

I didn't feel like I learned a lot in this class. The readings and lectures were a bit antiquated and I would have preferred to learn more about building interventions. Midterm was graded obscenely difficult for how easy it was and really didn't test my knowledge but ability to just memorize an article. The weekly summaries were a bit unnecessary too.
There was a lot of work, but the group and partner aspects of it made it more doable. The final paper was challenging but picking your own topic was helpful.
I think current literature would be more beneficial.

There is a lot of writing involved in this course.  A way this can be improved is rather than having weekly reading summaries due each week, having a part of the systematic due each week (or every other week) would help with the distribution of work and final product of the class.

This was a fantastic class that provided me with a thorough background knowledge of our topic by covering a wide variety of research and policy. The work load was heavy, especially with the in-depth summaries due every week, but making the systematic review process progressive and broken down throughout the semester was very helpful and made us confident in our end product.

The greatest strength was that this course taught us how to conduct a systematic review. The weekly summaries also were helpful because we had to practice concisely summarizing research  and we got feedback. The skills developed are generalizable. Also, content was interesting. 

Weakness was the class name. I think that if you branded it as a course in systematic reviews, using maternal and child health and nutrition as the content area, it would appeal to more students as they would better understand the utility of the course.

Professor Perez-Escamilla is clearly an expert in the field of global maternal and child nutrition, but he does not translate much of that competency to his teaching. Most lectures are a rehashing of random work he has done or that his peers have done, so there isn't a cohesive thread in the curriculum. He also does not make himself very available.
Need not to emphasize his publication in a high impact journal, which is not first or second author.

Professor Perez-Escamilla is delightful to work with and learn from. He really makes the work personable and it fosters a very welcoming class time. All of the lectures go together nicely and really highlight the important aspects of maternal child health.

Dr. Perez-Escamilla is an excellent professor! He is an expert in maternal child health and shares honest and insightful reflections from this work with us. He is an engaging lecturer, and I appreciate his kindness.
He's very experienced, but his lectures were a little hard to follow
Very nice and helpful! Gives helpful feedback and criticism. Both the professor and the TF devoted a lot of time to the class.
Dr. Perez-Escamilla is an amazing instructor and it was great having such a well published and expert in the field lecturing us on various topics.

The instructor was dedicated and responsive to our course, participants, and questions throughout the semester. We always received timely and thorough feedback on all of our assignments, which substantially contributed to my positive experience in the class and with the covered material.
Amazing.  Appreciated the expertise he brought as well as his clear superior ability as a lecturer. Learned a lot from him.

I would not recommend taking this course unless you specifically are interested in a research career in maternal and child nutrition. If you are just generally interested in public health, this class will not feel relevant at all.
The course is overall below average than other courses at Yale.
Excellent course. Would recommend to anyone interested in maternal child health or nutrition.
Pretty easy class, but didn't really feel like it was helpful to my career.
Challenging course but interesting subject!
Did not learn much from the course, would have liked to have more current literature and case studies to review.
I would recommend this course for students only if they have the time to dedicate to writing a lot on the topic of maternal and child health.

I would definitely recommend this course to a fellow student, cautioning them of the heavy workload through the semester, but emphasizing the strong knowledge base gained from the course and working with our instructor and TF.
Learning how to read, critically assess and conduct systematic reviews.
